problems.problem: Define the quantum mechanical model of the atom.

step_by_step.explanation: The quantum mechanical model describes electrons as existing in probabilistic orbitals around the nucleus rather than fixed paths.

problems.final_answer: Electrons exist in probabilistic orbitals; their exact position cannot be known.

step_by_step.explanation: It is impossible to know both the exact position and exact momentum of an electron simultaneously.

problems.final_answer: Δx·Δp ≥ h/4π; cannot know exact position and momentum at the same time.

step_by_step.explanation: An atomic orbital is a region of space around the nucleus where there is a high probability of finding an electron.

problems.final_answer: Atomic orbital: region of high probability of finding an electron.

problems.problem: List the four quantum numbers and their significance.

step_by_step.explanation: Indicates energy level/shell of the electron.
Indicates subshell (s, p, d, f) and shape of orbital.
Indicates orientation of orbital in space.
Indicates spin of the electron (+½ or -½).

problems.final_answer: n: energy level; l: subshell/shape; mₗ: orientation; mₛ: spin.

problems.problem: Describe the shapes of s, p, and d orbitals.

step_by_step.explanation: Cloverleaf shape (four lobes) or donut with dumbbell.

problems.final_answer: s: sphere; p: dumbbell; d: cloverleaf/donut-dumbbell.

step_by_step.explanation: No two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers.

problems.final_answer: Pauli Exclusion: no two electrons share all four quantum numbers.

step_by_step.explanation: Electrons occupy degenerate orbitals singly with parallel spins before pairing.

problems.final_answer: Hund's Rule: fill degenerate orbitals singly first with same spin.

problems.problem: Explain the difference between ground state and excited state of an electron.

step_by_step.explanation: Lowest energy configuration of electrons in an atom.
Electron absorbs energy and moves to a higher energy orbital.

problems.final_answer: Ground state: lowest energy; Excited state: electron in higher energy orbital.

problems.problem: Write the electron configuration of oxygen (O, Z=8) in ground state.
Explain why the quantum mechanical model replaced Bohr’s model.

step_by_step.explanation: Bohr’s model could not explain multi-electron atoms or the probabilistic nature of electron position; quantum mechanics accounts for orbital shapes and electron probabilities.

problems.final_answer: Quantum model explains multi-electron atoms and electron probability; Bohr’s model cannot.
